author: GlitchDead
body:
Even with a roadmap of what an EV should be, it'll be hard to copy what Tesla is capable of though unless Elon goes through with licensing his tech. Most automakers are probably using TI, Infineon, NXP or Renesas for processors and Nvidia for AI. Tesla I believe made their own silicon since what is available now wasn't powerful enough. Also at this point ML/AI (used for things like object detection) is primarily based on having a bunch of data collected, which every Tesla car has been providing so they will have years of data over its competition. There was a cool video I watched where his SW/HW engineer were explaining what they were doing to be different.   


100% there will be EV competitors that take away Tesla's marketshare, but we are quickly shifting towards autonomous features and I think Tesla will be untouchable there, especially since a lot of the Auto OEM's we're thinking of use other companies for some of their designs like Delphi, Bosch or Continental who don't have the capacity to make their own silicon.  (I still think Tesla is overvalued though)

author: MichoRizo7698
body: NXPI zero day $123 CALLS

author: hak8or
body:
Please describe what inroads Intel has made into IOT compared to companies like Espressif, Nordic, Mediatek, or even traditional MCU companies like STM or NXP? Hell, even the x86 ISA is less common in IOT than risc-v. 

I have not seen any inroads from Intel into IOT that are worth much. IOT is an absurdly cost sensitive area, something Intel is very not experienced and seemingly comfortable with.

I have not seen a single Intel based device in IOT over the past few years. As very beefy gateways then maybe a handful at most. All smart plugs, sensors, etc, have been MCU's, something for which Intel has no reach and products worth a damn (as far as I know).

author: Skilk
body: Just remember that inflation is going up so your money is losing value as it sits in your bank account, regardless if the nominal value stays the same. There are relatively safe investments that will at least keep you near inflation. And if you do think keeping cash is the right move, buy Berkshire Hathaway cause they're at a huge discount still and sitting on record cash. I'm fairly confident that they are going to spend tons of it in the next market dive. I'm not sure I'd call BRK a "safe" investment but it's hard to bet against the Oracle of Omaha.

author: SleepyRevenant
body:
I work as a  data engineering consultant and I assure you, you can just port some dated corporate oracle/IBM setup to hadoop/kafka/spark/<whatever db the CTO likes the sound of> and make serious money doing it. Anything that can be done with data can be done (and is best done) with java/scala or a python interface for java/scala.

So apart from web frameworks (where spring is an option) and REST APIs (Just use a fucking JDBC) what exactly is so immensely resource intensive server side that you absolutely must use non-JVM compiled code for? Let's not forget that all important Python packages are readily available for ARM architecture so interpreted shit clearly isn't the problem.

I bet you're a ruby developer who thinks that your dying language is somehow not going to go the way of PHP.

author: hammondish
body:
Diversify across big and small... for long term it's all relative, and big = stability with less risk.

I got inti  buying tech stocks around the end of 2016: GOOG, AMZN, FB: about as big as they get, but all were excellent buys and over 100% gains across the board.
On the smaller side, PYPL worked put pretty well too... with slightly more upside: the point is GROWTH POTENTIAL, and CRM has this plus stability.
Makes it, IMO, an ideal investment.

author: ThatOneRedditBro
body:
RAZFF (Razer)

1. Hardware sales are up. Work from home is here to stay. Minimal competitors in the market. They also sell web cams which is a high growth sector.

2. Gaming and eSports is only getting bigger

3. They are experimenting into Fintech which is exploding right now (PayPal, square, crypto) and their financial services sector is growing year of year

4. Their services sector is growing (Razer software)

5. 500 million cash and no debt

6. Competitors like Logitech produced during pandemic and has positive guidance 

One of the top brands for gen z.

All in all they are dabbling in key high growth sectors and delivering on all of them.

author: fateholder
body:
Going with one company makes sense in some scenarios (AMD over INTC for example) when you have expertise/knowledge of the field giving you some edge and a belief that one will outperform the other.

In other scenarios, such as MA v V, I think it makes plenty sense to own both. This field will have more than one winner, and both will coexist well. They also largely move in lockstep with each other, but by diversifying between the two, you do decrease the risk/volatility that each inherently hold (idk like a scandal with one of them, etc.) and its more a bet on the sector/trend sticking with strong companies that will benefit.

For SQ v PYPL, I actually think they are different enough it warrants investing in one or both depending on your view of their individual futures. PYPL is more of a cashless play whereas SQ has both the Seller ecosystem, cashless (cashapp) and Square Store ecosystems.

author: hammondish
body:
I'm with this approach, the roughly $2k I lost trading penny stocks in 2014 was the best money I ever spent: learned the basics of trading, avoiding risk, reading through the hype, and towards the end of that batch of trading found Canopy Growth @$2.00, which turned into my first win (and it offset all my previous losses).  Learned the difference between a hyped up pump-and-dump and a legitimate company, and shifted my focus to more established companies, mainly in tech.

Since then I've followed a strategy similar to what the OP has done, buying stocks whose success is evident in my daily life and companies that demonstrate obvious value to their clients: I work as an IT consultant, so when I see that all my clients are using Paypal, building ecommerce sites with Shopify, and hooking up the CRMs with Salesforce, I research these companies and look for investment opportunities.

1. Stick with what you know

2. Trust your instinct

3. Buy for long term

body:
SQ Square

They are a peer-to-peer payment processing company. They have hardware and software that helps small businesses process many types of payments from the customer.

They also have the Cash App, an app similar to PayPal. Users can send and recieve money. Users can also buy cryptocurrencies on the app. The app is growing very rapidly.

body: I’m a big fan of ARKF. Square gonna pop off/ is popping off. I honestly have a bunch of all of them and don’t mind the overlap. If you watch or listen to Cathie Woods you’ll probs agree what they are doing is  pretty awesome... I also just own Microsoft PayPal etc as blue chips

author: willyourather
body: I have about 10% or less in ETFs in my portfolio and the rest is in individual stocks. I only do this because I have so many ETFs in my 401k and Roth. Luckily, most of my individual stocks have great returns since I’m a buy and hold investor. For me, AAPL and most tech stocks are winners. I tend to buy companies I know and see in daily life. PayPal, square, Shopify, AMD and amazon are my big holdings. Find stocks that you believe they will grow within 5-10 years and hold on them. Have a tight stop loss when things go down south to the point you are uncomfortable. Good luck!

author: c1utch10
body: This. Last Thursday after hours was hundreds of billions of dollars in share price gains across Google, Apple, Amazon, Facebook. Not to mention Paypal and Shopify that have some similarities to Square that had big rallies after earnings.

author: d10srespect
body: People can call me a stan, but how can any sensible person doubt Elon and his companies? If Elon wanted to start having Tesla make commerical aircrafts, he'd probably but Boeing and Airbus out of business in 10yrs. This one guy has been a major face of Paypal, Tesla, and now SpaceX. That doesn't even include his other companies such as The Boring Company or Neuralink. Musk is the Edison of our time and frankly, anyone who doubts him is just doing so out of ignorance and stupidity. All abord the Musk train man.
